title: Patriots rookie TreVeyon Henderson announces engagement
author: John Waller
bullets: Patriots rookie running back TreVeyon Henderson announced his engagement on Instagram, sharing a photo with his fiancée.
Henderson, a former Ohio State player, focuses on football and faith in his social media presence.
Patriots quarterback Drake Maye, recently married, could offer Henderson wedding-planning advice.

title: Red Sox rookie Connelly Early discussed his dominant MLB debut
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Connelly Early struck out 11 in his MLB debut, pitching five scoreless innings against the Athletics on Tuesday.
Boston Red Sox defeated the Oakland Athletics 6-0, with homers from Romy Gonzalez and Rob Refsnyder.
Early praised catcher Carlos Narváez for his preparation, crediting teamwork for their successful game plan.

title: One injured in Boston scaffolding collapse
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A construction worker was injured in a scaffolding collapse in Boston's South End on September 9, 2025.
The worker was extricated from the third floor and transported to a local hospital under concussion protocol.
OSHA and a building inspector are investigating the cause of the accident at 547 Albany Street.

title: Market Basket board votes to remove Arthur T. Demoulas
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Arthur T. Demoulas removed as Market Basket CEO following unanimous board vote amid corporate tensions.
Demoulas faced allegations of planning a work stoppage; his sisters hold a controlling 60% stake in the company.
Market Basket assures customers operations and company culture will remain unchanged following leadership removal.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Sept. 10)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Andover's 58 Abbot St., an antique home built in 1754, sold for $2,825,000, the highest in the area.
Ayer's 40 Washington St., built in 1890, was sold as a two-family property for $1,350,000.
Other notable sales include Arlington's 11 Williams St., a 1940 garrison style home, sold for $1,335,750.

title: Here’s who will be on the ballot in November’s 2025 City Council election
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Boston's preliminary election narrowed candidates for the City Council, with the general election set for November 4, 2025.
Ruthzee Louijeune leads the at-large city council race with 17.65% of the votes, aiming for re-election.
Gabriela Coletta Zapata leads District 1 race with 76.96% of votes, ensuring her position on the November ballot.

title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu leads by 45 percentage points over Josh Kraft in preliminary election results.
Wu and Kraft advance to November's mayoral election, with Wu's lead at about 26,400 votes.
Preliminary election saw a nearly 18% turnout, with more than 75,000 ballots cast by 6 p.m.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a San Francisco venture capitalist, sued surrogate Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage, claiming negligence.
Surrogacy industry growth highlights regulatory gaps, with rising interest from Silicon Valley investors and potential health risks.
Smith moved jobs and homes due to Bi's harassment, which included disparaging social media posts and job interference.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm returns to Bruins training camp healthy after missing 65 games with a fractured patella last season.
The Bruins struggled with a 33-39-10 record in 2024-25, partly due to Lindholm's absence impacting their defensive stability.
Lindholm aims to boost the Bruins' defense and power play, potentially improving their NHL standing this season.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bills QB Josh Allen praised Patriots QB Drake Maye, calling him a bright and talented young player.
Allen and Maye have developed a good relationship, with Allen advising Maye to stay authentic.
Maye, compared to Allen for his arm and scrambling ability, had a mixed performance in his season opener.
